# Problem Explanation
---
### Problem Interpretation  

#### Physical System Description  
• Two polar (electric‐dipole) molecules, labeled A and B, are considered in the x–y plane (Fig. 1a).  
• Molecule A is fixed at the origin O (0, 0).  
  – It carries a permanent electric dipole moment **p₁** of magnitude p directed strictly along the +y axis.  
• Molecule B has a permanent electric dipole moment **p₂** of the same magnitude p; the dipole makes an angle θ with the +y axis (measured positive by the usual right–hand convention, with −π < θ ≤ π).  
  – The centre of mass of B is constrained to lie on the horizontal line y = b (b > 0). Thus its Cartesian coordinates are (x, b) where x is free to vary.  
  – B is attached to a frictionless, perfectly insulating, massless axle that is perpendicular to the x–y plane and fixed to a smooth, straight rail running along y = b. The axle’s length is negligible so the centre of mass coincides with the rail position.  
  – B can translate along the rail (i.e., along the x direction) and can rotate about the axle, so θ can change with time.  
• The mass of molecule B is m. For convenience its moment of inertia about the axle is prescribed as I = (1/12) m b².  
• Gravitational effects are neglected.  
• The environment is vacuum with permittivity ε₀.  
• Unit vectors **eₓ** and **e_y** denote the +x and +y directions respectively.  

#### Variables and Parameters  
• p : common magnitude of the permanent dipole moments of A and B  
• **p₁** : dipole moment vector of molecule A (magnitude p, direction +y)  
• **p₂** : dipole moment vector of molecule B (magnitude p, direction making angle θ with +y)  
• θ (–π < θ ≤ π) : instantaneous orientation angle of **p₂** relative to +y  
• x : instantaneous x–coordinate of molecule B’s centre of mass  
• b (>0) : fixed y–coordinate of molecule B’s centre of mass / distance of rail from the x axis  
• m : mass of molecule B  
• I = (1/12) m b² : moment of inertia of molecule B about its axle (perpendicular to plane)  
• ε₀ : vacuum permittivity  
• **E₁** : electric field at the location of B produced by dipole A (to be determined)  
• Fₓ : x component of the force exerted on B by the field of A (to be determined)  
• M : torque on B about its axle due to the field of A (to be determined)  
• t : time  
• a : a small positive constant (0 < a ≪ b) used as the initial x–position in part (4)  

#### Initial Conditions  
• General analysis in parts (1)–(3): no specific initial conditions are imposed (the resulting expressions may contain integration constants).  
• Specific initial release for part (4):  
  – At t = 0: x = a, θ = 0  
  – B is released from rest: ẋ = 0, θ̇ = 0  

#### Constraints and Assumptions  
1. Molecule A is immobile and its dipole orientation is fixed.  
2. Molecule B is restricted to move only along the rail (horizontal line y = b); thus yB = b is constant.  
3. Molecule B can freely rotate about the perpendicular axle; its motion is planar except for this out-of-plane rotation.  
4. The axle and rail are perfectly smooth and massless; no frictional or resistive forces are present.  
5. Gravitational forces are neglected.  
6. Both molecules are treated as ideal point dipoles; only electric dipole–dipole interactions are considered.  
7. The medium is vacuum; hence Coulomb’s law uses ε₀.  
8. Small‐angle or small‐displacement approximations may become relevant when stability near equilibrium is studied (as implied in part (3)).  
9. The notation I = (1/12) m b² is taken as given for computational convenience.  

#### Solution Objective  
1. Determine the electric field **E₁** at the position of molecule B due to the dipole **p₁** of molecule A.  
2. From **E₁**, find  
   a. The x-component of the electric force on molecule B, Fₓ,  
   b. The torque M on molecule B about its axle,  
   c. The condition(s) under which molecule B remains completely at rest (no translation, no rotation).  
3. Investigate the stability of the equilibrium configuration that corresponds to the smaller value of |θ|; obtain general expressions for x(t) and θ(t) for small deviations from that equilibrium (results may contain undetermined integration constants owing to unspecified initial data).  
4. For the specific initial release (x = a, θ = 0, released from rest), derive explicit time-dependent functions x(t) and θ(t).

# Solution
---
# Refined Solution

### Step 1  
\[\boxed{\mathbf R = x\,\mathbf e_x + b\,\mathbf e_y}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf R &\equiv \text{position vector from dipole A (origin) to B } (x,b)
          = x\,\mathbf e_x + b\,\mathbf e_y .
\label{eq:R} \tag{1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2  
\[\boxed{r=|\mathbf R|=\sqrt{x^{2}+b^{2}}},\qquad
\boxed{\hat{\mathbf R}=\dfrac{\mathbf R}{r}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
r &= \sqrt{x^{2}+b^{2}}, &
\hat{\mathbf R} &= \frac{\mathbf R}{r} = \frac{x\,\mathbf e_x + b\,\mathbf e_y}{\sqrt{x^{2}+b^{2}}}.
\label{eq:rhat} \tag{2}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3  
\[\boxed{\displaystyle
\mathbf E_{\text{dip}}(\mathbf R)=\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
\frac{3(\mathbf p\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf R})\hat{\mathbf R}-\mathbf p}{r^{3}}
}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf p_1 &= p\,\mathbf e_y,  \nonumber\\
\mathbf p_1\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf R} &= p\,\mathbf e_y\!\cdot\!\hat{\mathbf R}=p\frac{b}{r}, \nonumber\\
\mathbf E_1(x,b) &= \frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\,
\frac{3(p b/r)\,\hat{\mathbf R}-p\,\mathbf e_y}{r^{3}} \nonumber\\
&= \frac{p}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
\frac{3bx\,\mathbf e_x+(2b^{2}-x^{2})\,\mathbf e_y}{(x^{2}+b^{2})^{5/2}} .
\label{eq:E1} \tag{3}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4  
\[\boxed{\mathbf p_2 = p\sin\theta\,\mathbf e_x + p\cos\theta\,\mathbf e_y}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\text{Dipole moment of B: }\;
\mathbf p_2 = p(\sin\theta\,\mathbf e_x + \cos\theta\,\mathbf e_y) .
\label{eq:p2} \tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 5  
\[\boxed{\mathbf M = \mathbf p_2 \times \mathbf E_1}\]

\[
\begin{align}
M &\equiv (\mathbf M)_z =
(p\sin\theta\,\mathbf e_x + p\cos\theta\,\mathbf e_y)
          \times
\Big(E_{1x}\,\mathbf e_x + E_{1y}\,\mathbf e_y\Big)\!\cdot\!\mathbf e_z \nonumber\\
&= p\sin\theta\,E_{1y}-p\cos\theta\,E_{1x} \nonumber\\
&= \frac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
\frac{(2b^{2}-x^{2})\sin\theta-3bx\cos\theta}{(x^{2}+b^{2})^{5/2}} .
\label{eq:M} \tag{5}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 6  
\[\boxed{\mathbf F=(\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\boldsymbol\nabla)\mathbf E_1
             =\boldsymbol\nabla\bigl(\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_1\bigr)}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_1
    &= \left(p\sin\theta\,\mathbf e_x+p\cos\theta\,\mathbf e_y\right)\!
       \cdot\!\mathbf E_1 \nonumber\\
    &= \frac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
       \frac{3bx\sin\theta + (2b^{2}-x^{2})\cos\theta}{(x^{2}+b^{2})^{5/2}}, \nonumber\\[4pt]
F_x &= \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\!\left(\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_1\right) \nonumber\\
    &= 3\,\frac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
       \frac{(b^{3}-4bx^{2})\sin\theta + (x^{3}-4b^{2}x)\cos\theta}
            {(x^{2}+b^{2})^{7/2}} .
\label{eq:Fx} \tag{6}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 7  
\[\boxed{F_x=0},\qquad \boxed{M=0}\]

\[
\begin{align}
(b^{3}-4bx^{2})\sin\theta + (x^{3}-4b^{2}x)\cos\theta &= 0, \label{eq:Fx0} \tag{7a}\\
(2b^{2}-x^{2})\sin\theta - 3bx\cos\theta &= 0. \label{eq:M0} \tag{7b}
\end{align}
\]

Solving \eqref{eq:Fx0}–\eqref{eq:M0}:  

\[
x\!\left(x^{4}+6b^{2}x^{2}+5b^{4}\right)=0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad x=0.
\]

Substituting into \eqref{eq:M0}:  

\[
\sin\theta=0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad \theta=0,\;\pi.
\]

Hence equilibrium points:

\[
\boxed{(x,\theta)=(0,0)\ \text{(parallel)}} ,\qquad
\boxed{(x,\theta)=(0,\pi)\ \text{(anti-parallel)}} .
\]

### Step 8  
\[\boxed{U = -\,\mathbf p_2\!\cdot\!\mathbf E_1}\]

\[
\begin{align}
U(x,\theta)
&=-\,\frac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
  \frac{3bx\sin\theta + (2b^{2}-x^{2})\cos\theta}{(x^{2}+b^{2})^{5/2}} .
\label{eq:U} \tag{8}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 9  
\[\boxed{T=\tfrac12 m\dot x^{2}+\tfrac12 I\dot\theta^{2}},\qquad
\boxed{I=\tfrac{1}{12}mb^{2}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
L &= T-U \nonumber\\
  &= \frac12 m\dot x^{2} + \frac12 I\dot\theta^{2}
     + \frac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
       \frac{3bx\sin\theta + (2b^{2}-x^{2})\cos\theta}{(x^{2}+b^{2})^{5/2}} .
\label{eq:L} \tag{9}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 10  
\[\boxed{|x|\ll b,\;|\theta|\ll1,\quad x=bu},\qquad
\boxed{\alpha=\dfrac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 b^{3}}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
U &\simeq -2\alpha + \alpha\left(\theta^{2}+6u^{2}-3u\theta\right), \nonumber\\
T &= \frac12 m b^{2}\dot u^{2} + \frac12 I\dot\theta^{2}.
\label{eq:quad} \tag{10}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 11  
\[\boxed{\dfrac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial\dot q}-\frac{\partial L}{\partial q}=0}\]

\[
\begin{align}
m b^{2}\ddot u + 12\alpha u - 3\alpha\theta &= 0, \nonumber\\
I\ddot\theta + 2\alpha\theta - 3\alpha u &= 0.
\label{eq:EOM} \tag{11}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 12  
\[\boxed{\text{Assume }u,\theta\propto e^{i\omega t}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\det
\begin{pmatrix}
- m b^{2}\omega^{2}+12\alpha & -3\alpha \\
-3\alpha & - I\omega^{2}+2\alpha
\end{pmatrix}=0 .
\end{align}
\]

With \(I=\tfrac{1}{12}mb^{2}\):

\[
\omega_{1}^{2}=\frac{30\alpha}{m b^{2}},\qquad
\omega_{2}^{2}=\frac{ 6\alpha}{m b^{2}} .
\label{eq:omega} \tag{12}
\]

Associated eigenvectors:  

• Mode 1 (ω₁): θ = −6u (high-frequency)  
• Mode 2 (ω₂): θ =  2u (low-frequency)

### Step 13  
\[\boxed{\text{General small-oscillation solution}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
x(t) &= b\!\Big[A\cos(\omega_{1}t+\delta)+B\cos(\omega_{2}t+\gamma)\Big], \nonumber\\
\theta(t) &= -6A\cos(\omega_{1}t+\delta)+2B\cos(\omega_{2}t+\gamma),
\label{eq:gensol} \tag{13}
\end{align}
\]
with constants \(A,B,\delta,\gamma\) fixed by initial data.

### Step 14  
\[\boxed{x(0)=a,\;\theta(0)=0,\;\dot x(0)=0,\;\dot\theta(0)=0}\]

\[
\begin{align}
b(A+B) &= a, \nonumber\\
-6A+2B &= 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad B=3A, \nonumber\\
\Longrightarrow\;A &= \frac{a}{4b},\quad B=\frac{3a}{4b},\quad
\delta=\gamma=0 .
\label{eq:IC} \tag{14}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 15  
\[\boxed{\text{Explicit motion after release}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
x(t) &= \frac{a}{4}\Big[\cos(\omega_{1}t)+3\cos(\omega_{2}t)\Big], \nonumber\\
\theta(t) &= \frac{3a}{2b}\Big[\cos(\omega_{2}t)-\cos(\omega_{1}t)\Big],
\label{eq:explicit} \tag{15}
\end{align}
\]
where  

\[
\omega_{1}^{2}=\frac{30p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 m b^{5}},\qquad
\omega_{2}^{2}=\frac{ 6p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 m b^{5}} .
\]

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
\text{(1) Electric field at B due to A: }\;
&\boxed{\displaystyle
\mathbf E_1(x,b)=\frac{p}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\;
\frac{3bx\,\mathbf e_x+(2b^{2}-x^{2})\,\mathbf e_y}{(x^{2}+b^{2})^{5/2}}} \\[10pt]
\text{(2) Force \(x\)-component and torque on B: }\;
&\boxed{\displaystyle
F_x=3\,\frac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\,
     \frac{(b^{3}-4bx^{2})\sin\theta+(x^{3}-4b^{2}x)\cos\theta}
          {(x^{2}+b^{2})^{7/2}}}, \\[6pt]
&\boxed{\displaystyle
M=\frac{p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\,
     \frac{(2b^{2}-x^{2})\sin\theta-3bx\cos\theta}
          {(x^{2}+b^{2})^{5/2}}} \\[6pt]
\text{Equilibrium conditions: }&(x,\theta)=(0,0)\ \text{(stable)},\;
(x,\theta)=(0,\pi)\ \text{(unstable)} \\[10pt]
\text{(3) Small-oscillation dynamics about \((0,0)\): }\;
&\boxed{\displaystyle
x(t)=b\big[A\cos(\omega_{1}t+\delta)+B\cos(\omega_{2}t+\gamma)\big]}, \\
&\boxed{\displaystyle
\theta(t)=-6A\cos(\omega_{1}t+\delta)+2B\cos(\omega_{2}t+\gamma)}, \\
&\boxed{\displaystyle
\omega_{1}^{2}=\frac{30p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 m b^{5}},\qquad
\omega_{2}^{2}=\frac{ 6p^{2}}{4\pi\varepsilon_0 m b^{5}}} \\[10pt]
\text{(4) Released from rest at }x=a,\;\theta=0\ \text{(}t=0\text{): }\;
&\boxed{\displaystyle
x(t)=\frac{a}{4}\Big[\cos(\omega_{1}t)+3\cos(\omega_{2}t)\Big]}, \\
&\boxed{\displaystyle
\theta(t)=\frac{3a}{2b}\Big[\cos(\omega_{2}t)-\cos(\omega_{1}t)\Big]} .
\end{align}
\]

(2) 弦线中同时存在沿 $x$ 轴正方向和负方向传播的简谐波时，将这两列波在 $x=x_1$ 处的复振幅分别记为 $\tilde{A}_1$、$\tilde{B}_1$，在 $x=x_2$ 处的复振幅分别记为 $\tilde{A}_2$、$\tilde{B}_2$，$\tilde{A}_2$、$\tilde{B}_2$ 可用 $\tilde{A}_1$、$\tilde{B}_1$ 表示为

# Problem Explanation

### Problem Interpretation  

#### Physical System Description  
1. General setting: Small-amplitude, one–dimensional transverse harmonic waves, propagating along the x–axis on stretched strings (elastic media).  
2. A string (or composite of strings) is considered “elastic medium”; when such strings are arranged periodically they constitute a one-dimensional “phononic crystal”.  
3. Four specific configurations are examined (illustrated in Fig. 2 a–d):  
   a) Fig. 2a – A single, uniform, infinitely long string characterised by constant linear mass density ρ and constant tension τ along the x–axis.  
   b) Fig. 2b – Two different semi-infinite strings (string 1 for x<0, string 2 for x>0) joined at x=0; the two sides can have different tensions.  
   c) Fig. 2c – A finite three-segment composite: starting from x=0^– a semi-infinite string 2, then (to the right) a segment of string 1 of length a, followed by a segment of string 2 of length b, then another segment of string 1 of length a, and finally a semi-infinite string 2 for x>(2a+b).  
   d) Fig. 2d – An infinite, periodic alternation of string 1 (length a) and string 2 (length b), giving a lattice period d = a + b; this is the one-dimensional phononic crystal.  
4. Gravity is neglected throughout (strings are assumed horizontal or its influence ignored).  
5. Waves are transverse (displacements along y-direction, propagation along x-direction) and of small amplitude, so linear wave theory applies.  

#### Variables and Parameters  
• y(x,t) : Real transverse displacement of the string element at position x and time t.  
• A   : Amplitude of the harmonic wave.  
• φ₀  : Initial phase of the harmonic wave.  
• k   : Wave number (magnitude of wave-vector) in a given uniform string; related to ω, ρ, τ through the dispersion relation of a stretched string.  
• ω   : Angular frequency of the harmonic wave (single frequency considered).  
• ṽy(x,t) : Complex representation of the transverse displacement.  
• ṽA(x) : Complex amplitude of the wave at position x; for a single forward-propagating wave ṽA(x)=Ae^{i(kx+φ₀)}.  
• ρ, ρ₁, ρ₂  : Linear mass densities of the uniform string (ρ) or of string 1 (ρ₁) and string 2 (ρ₂).  
• τ, τ₁, τ₂  : Tensions in the uniform string (τ) or in string 1 (τ₁) and string 2 (τ₂); they can differ across an interface.  
• ε_k(x,t) : Instantaneous kinetic-energy density (per unit undeformed length) of the string at point x and time t.  
• ε_p(x,t) : Instantaneous potential-energy density (per unit undeformed length) of the string at point x and time t; defined to be zero when no wave is present.  
• I(x,t) : Instantaneous energy flux (power per unit transverse width) at x, t along the x-direction.  
• ȒI   : Time-averaged energy flux (over a full period).  
• ṽA₁, ṽB₁ : Complex amplitudes of forward (+x) and backward (–x) travelling waves, respectively, evaluated at x=x₁.  
• ṽA₂, ṽB₂ : Same quantities evaluated at x=x₂.  
• \hat{M}  : General 2×2 transmission (transfer) matrix mapping amplitudes at x₁ to those at x₂.  
• \hat{M}_{12}, \hat{M}_{212} : Specific transfer matrices for composite segments defined in parts (2) and (3).  
• a, b   : Physical lengths of string 1 and string 2 segments in composite systems.  
• d    : Spatial period of the phononic crystal, d = a + b.  
• K    : Bloch wavevector in the periodic structure.  
• ṽu_K(x) : Periodic complex amplitude (period d) in Bloch form.  
• v_p   : Phase velocity in the long-wavelength (K→0) limit for the lowest band.  
• T    : Power (energy-flux) transmission coefficient, T = ȒI_t / ȒI_i.  
• ṽt    : Complex amplitude transmission coefficient for the composite in part (3), ṽt = ṽA_t / ṽA_i.  
• Δω   : Width of a frequency band gap (forbidden band).  
• K₀   : Edge of the first Brillouin zone for this 1-D lattice, K₀ = π/d.  
• δK   : Small deviation of K from K₀ (|δK| ≪ K₀).  
• ε(K)  : Phonon energy as a function of Bloch wavevector.  
• m*   : Effective mass of a phonon at K=K₀.  
• ħ    : Reduced Planck constant.

#### Initial Conditions  
• For part (1): At t=0 the travelling wave has initial phase φ₀ = 0; the string is otherwise in its unperturbed (straight) state with zero potential energy reference.  
• For parts (2)–(4): A harmonic wave is incident from “left infinity” (x→−∞) on the composite or periodic structure, implying purely forward-propagating waves in the leftmost semi-infinite region before reaching any interface. No explicit time dependence beyond the harmonic factor e^{-iωt}.  

#### Constraints and Assumptions  
1. Small-amplitude (linear) transverse oscillations; superposition principle holds.  
2. Strings are ideal: perfectly flexible, perfectly elastic, no internal damping, uniform within each segment, constant tension in each segment.  
3. Gravity is neglected.  
4. Interfaces (x=0, x=a, x=a+b, …) may connect strings with different tensions; appropriate continuity/force conditions apply (to be used later in solution).  
5. For periodic structure (Fig. 2d) Bloch theorem applies; mechanical wave solutions take Bloch form ṽu_K(x)e^{iKx}.  
6. Energy densities and fluxes are defined per unit original (unstretched) length, referenced so that the un-perturbed string has zero potential energy.  
7. In part (4.3), δK is assumed small compared with K₀ so that a quadratic (parabolic) expansion of ε(K) is valid.

#### Solution Objective  
Part (1):  
a) Determine expressions for instantaneous kinetic-energy density ε_k(x,t).  
b) Determine expressions for instantaneous potential-energy density ε_p(x,t) (zero reference when no wave).  
c) Obtain instantaneous energy flux I(x,t).  
d) Obtain time-averaged energy flux ȒI.

Part (2):  
a) Find the transfer matrix \hat{M}_{12} across a single interface at x=0 between string 1 and string 2.  
b) For a wave incident from x→−∞, calculate the transmission coefficient T = ȒI_t / ȒI_i.

Part (3):  
a) For the finite three-segment structure (string 2 – string 1 – string 2 – string 1 – string 2) from x=0^− to x=a^+, derive the composite transfer matrix \hat{M}_{212}, and express every matrix element ṽz as Re(ṽz) + i Im(ṽz).  
b) For an incident wave from x→−∞, find the complex amplitude transmission coefficient ṽt = ṽA_t / ṽA_i at x = (2a + b)^+.

Part (4):  
a) Derive the dispersion relation ω(K) for Bloch waves in the infinite periodic structure; then, for the lowest pass band, determine the phase velocity v_p in the long-wavelength limit K→0.  
b) With specific parameters ρ₁ = 2ρ₂, τ₁ = 2τ₂, a = 2b, compute the frequency ranges of all band gaps (forbidden bands) and the corresponding bandwidths Δω, expressed in terms of ρ₂, τ₂, and b.  
c) For the lowest pass band of the same structure, determine the phonon effective mass m* at K = K₀ = π/d, expressing the result with ħ, ρ₂, τ₂, and b.

#### Geometric / Spatial Relations  
• Single string: entire x-axis.  
• Two-string interface: boundary at x = 0 between semi-infinite regions (x<0: string 1; x>0: string 2).  
• Three-segment composite:  
   – Region ordering for x≥0: string 1 of length a (0 to a), string 2 of length b (a to a+b), string 1 of length a (a+b to 2a+b).  
   – Semi-infinite string 2 extends to x<0 and x>2a+b.  
• Periodic crystal: infinite repetition of sequence [string 1 length a] + [string 2 length b]; lattice constant d = a + b.

#### Boundary and Matching Conditions  
• At every interface between two string segments, continuity of transverse displacement y and of transverse force (τ ∂y/∂x) is required; tensions τ₁, τ₂ may differ.  
• For semi-infinite regions, only outgoing (or incident) travelling waves exist according to the physical scattering scenario:  
   – Leftmost region (x→−∞): incident + reflected waves.  
   – Rightmost region (x→+∞): transmitted wave only.  
• For periodic structure, Bloch periodicity: ṽy(x+d,t) = ṽy(x,t) e^{iKd}.

# Refined Solution

### Step 1  
\[\boxed{\rho\frac{\partial^{2}y}{\partial t^{2}}=\tau\frac{\partial^{2}y}{\partial x^{2}}}\]  
\[\begin{align}
\text{For }y(x,t)=A\cos(kx-\omega t)\; &\Longrightarrow\; 
\rho(-\omega^{2})A\cos= \tau(-k^{2})A\cos, \\[2pt]
\therefore\; &\boxed{\omega^{2}=v^{2}k^{2}},\quad 
\boxed{v=\sqrt{\tau/\rho}}\label{eq:disp}\tag{1}
\end{align}\]

### Step 2  
\[\boxed{\frac{\partial y}{\partial t}=+A\omega\sin(kx-\omega t)},\qquad
  \boxed{\frac{\partial y}{\partial x}=-Ak\sin(kx-\omega t)}\]  
\[\begin{align}
\partial_t y &= -A\sin(kx-\omega t)(-\omega)=A\omega\sin(kx-\omega t),\\[2pt]
\partial_x y &= -A k\sin(kx-\omega t).\label{eq:der}\tag{2}
\end{align}\]

### Step 3  
\[\boxed{\varepsilon_{k}(x,t)=\tfrac12\rho\bigl(\partial_t y\bigr)^2}\]  
\[\begin{align}
\varepsilon_{k}(x,t)=\tfrac12\rho A^{2}\omega^{2}\sin^{2}(kx-\omega t).\label{eq:Ek}\tag{3}
\end{align}\]

### Step 4  
\[\boxed{\varepsilon_{p}(x,t)=\tfrac12\tau\bigl(\partial_x y\bigr)^2}\]  
\[\begin{align}
\varepsilon_{p}(x,t)=\tfrac12\tau A^{2}k^{2}\sin^{2}(kx-\omega t)
=\tfrac12\rho A^{2}\omega^{2}\sin^{2}(kx-\omega t)\quad(\text{using } \ref{eq:disp}).\label{eq:Ep}\tag{4}
\end{align}\]

### Step 5  
\[\boxed{\langle\sin^{2}\theta\rangle=\tfrac12}\]  
\[\begin{align}
\overline{\varepsilon} 
&=\bigl\langle \varepsilon_k+\varepsilon_p\bigr\rangle
 =\rho A^{2}\omega^{2}\langle\sin^{2}\theta\rangle
 =\tfrac12\rho A^{2}\omega^{2}.\label{eq:Eavg}\tag{5}
\end{align}\]

### Step 6  
\[\boxed{I(x,t)=-\tau\,\partial_x y\,\partial_t y}\]  
\[\begin{align}
I(x,t)&=-\tau(-Ak\sin\theta)(A\omega\sin\theta)
       =-\tau k\omega A^{2}\sin^{2}\theta, \\[2pt]
\overline I&=-\tfrac12\tau k\omega A^{2}.\label{eq:Iavg}\tag{6}
\end{align}\]

### Step 7  
\[\boxed{Z\equiv\frac{\tau k}{\omega}=\sqrt{\tau\rho}}\]  
\[\begin{align}
Z=\frac{\tau}{v}=\sqrt{\tau\rho}.\label{eq:Z}\tag{7}
\end{align}\]

### Step 8  
\[\boxed{\tilde y(x)=\tilde A\,e^{ikx}+\tilde B\,e^{-ikx}}\]  
\[\begin{align}
\text{Here }\tilde A(\tilde B)\text{ are complex amplitudes of waves travelling }\pm x.
\end{align}\]

### Step 9  
\[\boxed{\text{continuity of }y},\qquad
  \boxed{\text{continuity of }\tau\partial_x y}\]  
\[\begin{align}
\tilde A_1+\tilde B_1&=\tilde A_2+\tilde B_2,\\
Z_1(\tilde A_1-\tilde B_1)&=Z_2(\tilde A_2-\tilde B_2).\label{eq:bc}\tag{9}

### Step 10

\end{align}\]

### Step 11  
\[\boxed{\hat M_{21}=\hat M_{12}^{-1}=
\frac{1}{2Z_1}\begin{pmatrix} Z_1+Z_2 & Z_1-Z_2\\ Z_1-Z_2 & Z_1+Z_2 \end{pmatrix}}\]  
\[\begin{align}

\end{align}\]

\[\boxed{\hat P_i(\ell)=
\begin{pmatrix} e^{ik_i\ell} & 0\\ 0 & e^{-ik_i\ell} \end{pmatrix}}\]

# Problem Explanation
---
### Problem Interpretation  

#### Physical System Description  
We consider a three-body gravitational system consisting of the massive bodies  
• S₁ with mass m₁  
• S₂ with mass m₂  
and a much smaller body  
• S₃ with mass m₃, where m₃ ≪ m₁, m₂.  

The influence of S₃ on S₁ and S₂ is neglected.  
S₁ and S₂ revolve with uniform circular motion about their common center of mass O.  
The distance between S₁ and S₂ is R.  

Certain points in space exist (Lagrange points) at which S₃ can remain at rest relative to S₁ and S₂ when placed there.  
Gravitational interactions are characterized by the universal constant G.  
Two mass ratios are introduced:  
α = m₂ / (m₁ + m₂) and β = 1 − α.  

Parts (2), (3), and (4) treat the special case α ≪ 1.  

The problem is split into four tasks:  
1. determine the angular velocity ω of S₁ and S₂ about O;  
2. locate all Lagrange points;  
3. assess the stability of the Lagrange point closest to S₂;  
4. study small motions of S₃ near that same point, restricting the dynamical equations to first-order (linear) terms in the displacement, and find both the time dependence of S₃’s position and the constraints on its initial displacement and velocity that eliminate exponentially growing departures.  

#### Variables and Parameters  
• m₁: mass of S₁  
• m₂: mass of S₂  
• m₃: mass of S₃ (m₃ ≪ m₁, m₂)  
• G: gravitational constant  
• R: fixed distance between S₁ and S₂  
• O: center of mass of S₁ and S₂; rotation center of their relative motion  
• ω: angular velocity of S₁ and S₂ about O (to be found in part 1)  
• α = m₂ / (m₁ + m₂) (used especially in parts 2–4; assumed α ≪ 1 there)  
• β = 1 − α  
• Lagrange points: spatial locations where S₃ can remain fixed in the rotating frame (to be determined in part 2)  
• Position vector(s) of S₃ (exact notation not specified, but its time evolution is required in part 4)  
• Initial displacement (small offset of S₃ from the chosen Lagrange point, part 4)  
• Initial velocity of S₃ relative to the rotating frame (part 4)  

#### Initial Conditions  
General initial conditions are not explicitly given for parts 1–3.  
For part 4:  
• S₃ is placed close to (but not exactly at) the Lagrange point closest to S₂.  
• Its initial displacement from that point and its initial velocity are controllable parameters.  

No further numerical values or specific vectors are supplied.  

#### Constraints and Assumptions  
1. m₃ is so small that its gravitational effect on S₁ and S₂ can be ignored.  
2. S₁ and S₂ execute uniform circular motion about their center of mass; the separation R is constant.  
3. For parts 2–4, α ≪ 1 (i.e., m₂ ≪ m₁ + m₂), permitting approximations inherent in that limit.  
4. Part 4 employs the linear (first-order) approximation in the displacement of S₃ from the Lagrange point; higher-order terms are neglected.  
5. Exponential growth of deviations (i.e., unstable modes) is to be suppressed by suitably choosing initial conditions in part 4.  

#### Solution Objective  
1. Determine ω, the angular velocity of S₁ and S₂ around O.  
2. Identify the positions of all Lagrange points relative to S₁, S₂, and O.  
3. Evaluate whether the equilibrium of S₃ at the Lagrange point nearest S₂ is stable or unstable.  
4. a) Obtain an explicit expression for the time dependence of S₃’s position when it undergoes small oscillations about that Lagrange point (linearized dynamics).  
   b) Derive the conditions on S₃’s initial displacement and initial velocity that preclude exponentially growing deviations.

# Solution
---
# Refined Solution

### Step 1  
\[\boxed{m_{1}\mathbf r_{1}+m_{2}\mathbf r_{2}=0}\]  
\[\boxed{r_{1}+r_{2}=R}\]

\[\boxed{\alpha=\dfrac{m_{2}}{m_{1}+m_{2}}},\qquad  
\boxed{\beta=1-\alpha}\]

\[
\begin{align}
x_{1}&=-\alpha R, & x_{2}&=+\beta R, \tag{1.1}\label{eq:S1S2}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2  
\[\boxed{\dfrac{Gm_{1}m_{2}}{R^{2}}=m_{1}\omega^{2}r_{1}=m_{1}\omega^{2}\alpha R}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\omega^{2}=\frac{G\,(m_{1}+m_{2})}{R^{3}}
\label{eq:omega}\tag{2.1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3  
\[\boxed{\Omega(x,y)=\frac{Gm_{1}}{r_{1}}+\frac{Gm_{2}}{r_{2}}+\frac12\omega^{2}(x^{2}+y^{2})}\]

\[\boxed{
\begin{cases}
\ddot x-2\omega\dot y=\dfrac{\partial\Omega}{\partial x},\\
\ddot y+2\omega\dot x=\dfrac{\partial\Omega}{\partial y},
\end{cases}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
r_{1}&=\sqrt{(x+\alpha R)^{2}+y^{2}},&
r_{2}&=\sqrt{(x-\beta R)^{2}+y^{2}}
\tag{3.1}\label{eq:r1r2}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4  
\[\boxed{\nabla\Omega=0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad\text{Lagrange points}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
Gm_{1}\frac{x+\alpha R}{|x+\alpha R|^{3}}
+Gm_{2}\frac{x-\beta R}{|x-\beta R|^{3}}
+\omega^{2}x=0,\;\;y=0
\label{eq:colleq}\tag{4.1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 5  
\[\boxed{\alpha\ll1},\qquad  
\boxed{\rho=\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{3}\right)^{1/3}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
L_{1}&:\;x_{L_{1}}=(1-\alpha-\rho)R,\nonumber\\
L_{2}&:\;x_{L_{2}}=(1-\alpha+\rho)R,\nonumber\\
L_{3}&:\;x_{L_{3}}=-\left(1+\dfrac{5}{12}\alpha\right)R
\tag{5.1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 6  
\[\boxed{|S_{1}L_{4}|=|S_{2}L_{4}|=R}\]

\[
\begin{align}
x_{L_{4,5}}&=\Bigl(\tfrac12-\alpha\Bigr)R,\qquad
y_{L_{4,5}}=\pm\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}R
\tag{6.1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 7  
\[\boxed{\xi=x-x_{L_{1}},\qquad\eta=y}\]

\[\boxed{
\begin{cases}
\ddot\xi-2\omega\dot\eta=\Omega_{xx}^{(0)}\xi,\\
\ddot\eta+2\omega\dot\xi=\Omega_{yy}^{(0)}\eta,
\end{cases}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\Omega_{xx}^{(0)}=\left.\frac{\partial^{2}\Omega}{\partial x^{2}}\right|_{L_{1}},
\qquad
\Omega_{yy}^{(0)}=\left.\frac{\partial^{2}\Omega}{\partial y^{2}}\right|_{L_{1}}
\tag{7.1}\label{eq:lin}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 8  
\[\boxed{\Omega_{xx}=+\frac{2Gm_{1}}{r_{1}^{3}}+\frac{2Gm_{2}}{r_{2}^{3}}+\omega^{2}}\]  
\[\boxed{\Omega_{yy}=-\frac{Gm_{1}}{r_{1}^{3}}-\frac{Gm_{2}}{r_{2}^{3}}+\omega^{2}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
d_{1}&=(1-\rho)R,\qquad d_{2}=\rho R, \nonumber\\
Q&\equiv\frac{G(m_{1}+m_{2})}{R^{3}}
\Bigl[\tfrac{1-\alpha}{(1-\rho)^{3}}+\tfrac{\alpha}{\rho^{3}}\Bigr]
\simeq4\,\omega^{2},\nonumber\\
\Omega_{xx}^{(0)}&=2Q+\omega^{2}\simeq7\,\omega^{2},\nonumber\\
\Omega_{yy}^{(0)}&=-Q+\omega^{2}\simeq-5\,\omega^{2}.
\tag{8.1}
\end{align}
\]

Define  

\[
A\equiv\Omega_{xx}^{(0)}\approx+7\,\omega^{2},\qquad
C\equiv\Omega_{yy}^{(0)}\approx-5\,\omega^{2}.
\label{eq:AC}\tag{8.2}
\]

### Step 9  
\[\boxed{\xi,\eta\propto e^{\sigma t}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\begin{vmatrix}
\sigma^{2}-A&-2\omega\sigma\\
2\omega\sigma&\sigma^{2}-C
\end{vmatrix}=0
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\sigma^{4}+6\omega^{2}\sigma^{2}-35\omega^{4}=0
\label{eq:char}\tag{9.1}
\end{align}
\]

Put \(u=\sigma^{2}\):

\[
\begin{align}
u^{2}+6\omega^{2}u-35\omega^{4}=0
\;\Longrightarrow\;
u_{\pm}=\omega^{2}\!\bigl[-3\pm2\sqrt{11}\,\bigr].
\end{align}
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{
\sigma=\pm\lambda,\;\pm i\nu},\qquad
\lambda=\omega\sqrt{2\sqrt{11}-3}\approx1.91\,\omega,\;
\nu=\omega\sqrt{2\sqrt{11}+3}\approx3.10\,\omega.
\tag{9.2}
\]

Because a positive real \(\lambda\) exists, \(L_{1}\) is linearly **unstable**.

### Step 10  
\[\boxed{k(\sigma)=\dfrac{\sigma^{2}-A}{2\omega\sigma}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
k_{\lambda}&\equiv k(\lambda)=\frac{\lambda^{2}-A}{2\omega\lambda}
\approx2.79, \nonumber\\
k(i\nu)&=i\kappa,\quad
\kappa=\frac{A+\nu^{2}}{2\omega\nu}\approx0.424.
\tag{10.1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 11  
\[\boxed{\text{Superposition principle for linear systems}}\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\xi(t)&=P\,e^{\lambda t}+Q\,e^{-\lambda t}+C_{1}\cos\nu t+C_{2}\sin\nu t,\\
\eta(t)&= k_{\lambda}P\,e^{\lambda t}-k_{\lambda}Q\,e^{-\lambda t}
        +\kappa\bigl[-C_{1}\sin\nu t+C_{2}\cos\nu t\bigr].
\label{eq:gensol}\tag{11.1}
\end{aligned}
\]

### Step 12  
\[\boxed{P=Q=0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad\text{no exponential terms}}\]

Let initial data be \(\xi_{0},\;\eta_{0},\;\dot\xi_{0},\;\dot\eta_{0}\).  
With \(P=Q=0\)

\[
\begin{cases}
\xi(t)=\xi_{0}\cos\nu t+\dfrac{\dot\xi_{0}}{\nu}\sin\nu t,\\[6pt]
\eta(t)=\kappa\!\left[-\xi_{0}\sin\nu t+\dfrac{\dot\xi_{0}}{\nu}\cos\nu t\right].
\end{cases}\tag{12.1}
\]

Consistency at \(t=0\) demands  

\[
\boxed{\eta_{0}=\kappa\,\dfrac{\dot\xi_{0}}{\nu}},\qquad
\boxed{\dot\eta_{0}=-\kappa\,\nu\,\xi_{0}}.
\label{eq:cond}\tag{12.2}
\]

These two relations remove every unstable exponential mode.

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
&\textbf{(1) 角速度：}\quad
\boxed{\displaystyle\omega=\sqrt{\frac{G\,(m_{1}+m_{2})}{R^{3}}}}\\[10pt]
&\textbf{(2) 拉格朗日点坐标（取}\;\alpha\ll1\textbf{）：} \\
&\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
L_{1}&:\;(x,y)=\bigl[(1-\alpha-\rho)R,\,0\bigr],\\
L_{2}&:\;(x,y)=\bigl[(1-\alpha+\rho)R,\,0\bigr],\\
L_{3}&:\;(x,y)=\bigl[-(1+\tfrac{5}{12}\alpha)R,\,0\bigr],\\

L_{5}&:\;(x,y)=\bigl[(\tfrac12-\alpha)R,\;-\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}R\bigr],
\end{aligned}\quad
\rho=\Bigl(\tfrac{\alpha}{3}\Bigr)^{1/3}}\\[14pt]

  f(p) = (1/h³) exp[(μ – E(p)) / (k_B T)],  
 where spin degeneracy is neglected.  
• Dynamic (chemical) equilibrium is achieved for each reaction considered; therefore the sum of the chemical potentials of reactants equals that of products for every reaction at equilibrium.  
• The specific nuclear reactions discussed are:  
 1. General photodisintegration/formation of a nucleus  \(^{A}_{Z}\mathrm{X}\) :  
   \(^{A}_{Z}\mathrm{X} + \gamma \rightleftharpoons Z\,\mathrm{p} + N\,\mathrm{n}\)  
 2. Deuteron photodisintegration/formation:  
   \(\mathrm{D} + \gamma \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{p} + \mathrm{n}\)  
 3. Neutron–proton interconversion via leptons at high temperature (two inverse beta reactions):  
   \(\mathrm{n} + \nu_e \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{p} + \mathrm{e}^-\)  
   \(\mathrm{n} + \mathrm{e}^+ \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{p} + \bar{\nu}_e\)  

#### Variables and Parameters

2. k_B – Boltzmann constant.

6. E(p) – Single-particle energy corresponding to momentum p.

16. \(m_\mathrm{p}\) – Rest mass of the proton (given numerical value 938.272 MeV/c²).  
17. \(m_\mathrm{n}\) – Rest mass of the neutron (given numerical value 939.565 MeV/c²).  
18. c – Speed of light in vacuum.  
19. \(n_{\mathrm{p}}\) – Proton number density.  
20. \(n_{\mathrm{n}}\) – Neutron number density.  
21. \(n_{\mathrm{D}}\) – Deuteron number density.  
22. \(\gamma\) – Photon (chemical potential μ_γ = 0).  
23. \(\nu_e,\,\bar{\nu}_e\) – Electron neutrino and antineutrino (chemical potentials taken as zero at high T).  
24. \(e^-, e^+\) – Electron and positron (their chemical potentials are zero at high T).

#### Initial Conditions  
• Part (1): A system of identical nuclei at temperature T with given number density n.  
• Part (2): The reaction \(^{A}_{Z}\mathrm{X} + \gamma \rightleftharpoons Z\mathrm{p} + N\mathrm{n}\) is already in dynamic equilibrium at temperature T.  
• Part (3): The deuteron photodisintegration reaction is in dynamic equilibrium at temperature T.  
• Part (4):  
 – At T > 0.8 MeV/k_B (≈ 9.3 × 10⁹ K): proton–neutron interconversion via leptons proceeds rapidly and maintains chemical equilibrium; μ for photons, electrons/positrons, and neutrinos/antineutrinos are zero.  
 – At T < 0.8 MeV/k_B: the interconversion reactions “freeze out,” and proton/neutron number densities stop evolving (no further weak interaction equilibrium).

#### Constraints and Assumptions  
1. Particles (except photons) are non-relativistic because their thermal kinetic energies are negligible compared with rest-mass energies.  
2. Spin degeneracy factors are ignored.  
3. Photons have zero chemical potential (μ_γ = 0).  
4. At high temperature in part (4), electrons, positrons, neutrinos, and antineutrinos have zero chemical potential due to rapid pair creation/annihilation.  
5. Chemical equilibrium condition: for any reaction at equilibrium, the sum of the chemical potentials of reactants equals that of products.  
6. For part (5), every neutron is incorporated into a stable helium nucleus; neutron decay is neglected.  
7. The integral expression provided may be required for evaluating momentum integrals under Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics.  

#### Solution Objective  
The problem asks for five distinct results:  
1. Part (1): Determine the chemical potential μ of a non-relativistic nucleus of rest mass m at temperature T, given its number density n.  
2. Part (2): Derive the relationship (an explicit formula) linking the equilibrium number density of nucleus \(^{A}_{Z}\mathrm{X}\) to the number densities of protons (n_p) and neutrons (n_n) at temperature T.  
3. Part (3): Obtain an explicit expression for the ratio \(n_\mathrm{D} / (n_\mathrm{p} n_\mathrm{n})\) when the deuteron reaction is in equilibrium at temperature T.  
4. Part (4):  
 a) For T > 0.8 MeV/k_B, find the expression for the neutron-to-proton number-density ratio \(n_\mathrm{n}/n_\mathrm{p}\) under dynamic equilibrium with zero lepton and photon chemical potentials.  
 b) Determine the frozen-out value of \(n_\mathrm{n}/n_\mathrm{p}\) after the interconversion reactions cease below 0.8 MeV/k_B.  
5. Part (5): Using the frozen-out neutron fraction and assuming all neutrons bind into helium nuclei without decay, estimate the mass fraction of helium nuclei (fraction of total nuclear mass present as helium) in the universe.  

#### Geometric / Spatial Relations  
No geometric configurations, distances, or spatial orientations are relevant or specified; the problem is purely thermodynamic and statistical in nature.  

#### Boundary Conditions  
• Equilibrium (steady-state) conditions apply to each reaction at the specified temperatures.  
• For the early-universe context in parts (4) and (5), the system is assumed homogeneous and isotropic, with the entire particle ensemble sharing the same temperature T (as set by the cosmic background).

# Refined Solution

### Step 1  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{f(\mathbf p)=\dfrac{1}{h^{3}}\exp\!\left[\dfrac{\mu-E(\mathbf p)}{k_{\!B}T}\right]}\]  
\[\boxed{E(\mathbf p)=mc^{2}+\dfrac{\mathbf p^{2}}{2m}\quad\text{(non-relativistic limit)}}\]  
\[\boxed{\text{Spin degeneracy is neglected }(g=1)}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
n &\equiv \int f(\mathbf p)\,d^{3}p \nonumber\\
  &=\frac{1}{h^{3}}\exp\!\Bigl[\tfrac{\mu-mc^{2}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr]
     \int e^{-\frac{p^{2}}{2mk_{\!B}T}}\,d^{3}p
     \label{eq:n_def}\tag{1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} e^{-a p^{2}}\,dp=\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}},\qquad a>0}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
\int e^{-\frac{p^{2}}{2mk_{\!B}T}}d^{3}p
      &=\left[\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}e^{-\frac{p_{x}^{2}}{2mk_{\!B}T}}dp_{x}\right]^{3}
      =\bigl(\sqrt{2\pi mk_{\!B}T}\bigr)^{3}           \nonumber\\
      &=(2\pi mk_{\!B}T)^{3/2}.
      \label{eq:gauss}\tag{2}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\lambda\equiv\frac{h}{\sqrt{2\pi m k_{\!B}T}}\qquad\text{(thermal de-Broglie wavelength)}}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
n &=\frac{1}{h^{3}}(2\pi mk_{\!B}T)^{3/2}
     \exp\!\Bigl[\tfrac{\mu-mc^{2}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr] \nonumber\\[2pt]
  &=\frac{1}{\lambda^{3}}\exp\!\Bigl[\tfrac{\mu-mc^{2}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr].
     \label{eq:n_lambda}\tag{3}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\text{Invert Eq.\,(3) to obtain }\mu}\]

Derivation  
\[
\begin{align}
\mu &= mc^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln\!\bigl(n\lambda^{3}\bigr)                \nonumber\\
    &= mc^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln\!\Bigl[\frac{nh^{3}}{(2\pi m k_{\!B}T)^{3/2}}\Bigr].
       \label{eq:mu_result}\tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 5  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\sum_{\text{reactants}}\mu=\sum_{\text{products}}\mu\quad\text{(chemical equilibrium)}}\]  
\[\boxed{\mu_\gamma=0}\]

Derivation  
For the reaction \(^{A}_{Z}\mathrm X+\gamma \rightleftharpoons Z\,\mathrm p+N\,\mathrm n\),
\[
\begin{align}
\mu_{X}+\mu_{\gamma}=Z\mu_{p}+N\mu_{n}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\mu_{X}=Z\mu_{p}+N\mu_{n}.
\label{eq:mu_balance}\tag{5}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 6  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{B_{X}= \bigl(Zm_{p}+Nm_{n}-m_{X}\bigr)c^{2}}\]

Derivation  
Insert Eq. \eqref{eq:mu_result} for each species in Eq. \eqref{eq:mu_balance}:
\[
\begin{align}
m_{X}c^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln(n_{X}\lambda_{X}^{3})
&=Z\Bigl[m_{p}c^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln(n_{p}\lambda_{p}^{3})\Bigr]
  +N\Bigl[m_{n}c^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln(n_{n}\lambda_{n}^{3})\Bigr] \nonumber\\
\Longrightarrow\;
\ln\!\bigl(n_{X}\lambda_{X}^{3}\bigr)
&=\ln\!\bigl((n_{p}\lambda_{p}^{3})^{Z}(n_{n}\lambda_{n}^{3})^{N}\bigr)
  +\frac{B_{X}}{k_{\!B}T}.
\label{eq:ln_relation}\tag{6}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 7  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\lambda_{i}=\frac{h}{\sqrt{2\pi m_{i}k_{\!B}T}}\quad(i=p,n,X,\ldots)}\]

Derivation  
Exponentiating Eq. \eqref{eq:ln_relation},
\[
\begin{align}
n_{X}
&=n_{p}^{\,Z}n_{n}^{\,N}
  \frac{\lambda_{p}^{3Z}\lambda_{n}^{3N}}{\lambda_{X}^{3}}
  \exp\!\Bigl[\frac{B_{X}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr].
\label{eq:saha_general}\tag{7}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 8  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\text{Deuteron reaction: }Z=N=1,\ X\to\mathrm D}\]

Derivation  
Setting \(Z=N=1\) in Eq. \eqref{eq:saha_general},
\[
\begin{align}
\frac{n_{\mathrm D}}{n_{\mathrm p}n_{\mathrm n}}
&=\frac{\lambda_{p}^{3}\lambda_{n}^{3}}{\lambda_{D}^{3}}
  \exp\!\Bigl[\frac{B_{D}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr] \nonumber\\
&=\frac{h^{3}}{(2\pi k_{\!B}T)^{3/2}}
  \left(\frac{m_{\mathrm p}m_{\mathrm n}}{m_{\mathrm D}}\right)^{3/2}
  \exp\!\Bigl[\frac{B_{D}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr].
\label{eq:deuteron}\tag{8}
\end{align}
\]
(The factor \((m_{\mathrm p}m_{\mathrm n}/m_{\mathrm D})^{3/2}\approx1\) but is kept for completeness.)

### Step 9  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\mu_{n}+\mu_{\nu_{e}}=\mu_{p}+\mu_{e^-}}\]  
\[\boxed{\mu_{n}+\mu_{e^{+}}=\mu_{p}+\mu_{\bar{\nu}_{e}}}\]  
\[\boxed{\mu_{\gamma}=\mu_{e^{\pm}}=\mu_{\nu_{e}}=\mu_{\bar{\nu}_{e}}=0\quad (T>0.8\;\text{MeV}/k_{\!B})}\]

Derivation  
At high \(T\) the above equalities give \(\mu_{n}=\mu_{p}\).  
Insert Eq. \eqref{eq:mu_result} for \(n,p\):
\[
\begin{align}
m_{n}c^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln(n_{n}\lambda_{n}^{3})
&=m_{p}c^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln(n_{p}\lambda_{p}^{3}) \nonumber\\
\Longrightarrow\;
\frac{n_{n}}{n_{p}}
&=\left(\frac{\lambda_{p}}{\lambda_{n}}\right)^{3}
  \exp\!\Bigl[-\frac{(m_{n}-m_{p})c^{2}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr] \nonumber\\
&=\left(\frac{m_{n}}{m_{p}}\right)^{3/2}
  \exp\!\Bigl[-\frac{\Delta m\,c^{2}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr],\qquad
  \Delta m\equiv m_{n}-m_{p}\simeq1.293\ \text{MeV}.
\label{eq:n_over_p}\tag{9}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 10  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{T_{f}=0.8\ \text{MeV}/k_{\!B}\quad\text{(freeze-out temperature)}}\]

Derivation  
Evaluating Eq. \eqref{eq:n_over_p} at \(T=T_{f}\):
\[
\begin{align}
r\equiv\left(\frac{n_{n}}{n_{p}}\right)_{\!\text{freeze}}
&\simeq\left(\frac{m_{n}}{m_{p}}\right)^{3/2}
       \exp\!\Bigl[-\frac{1.293\ \text{MeV}}{0.8\ \text{MeV}}\Bigr] \nonumber\\
&\approx1.002\,e^{-1.616}\approx0.20.
\label{eq:r_freeze}\tag{10}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 11  
Principles / Original Formulas / Assumptions  
\[\boxed{\text{All surviving neutrons bind into }{}^{4}\mathrm{He}\;(2p+2n)}\]

Derivation  
Let \(r=n_{n}/n_{p}\) after freeze-out.  
Total baryon number density: \(n_{B}=n_{p}+n_{n}=n_{p}(1+r)\).  
Number density of produced helium nuclei: \(n_{He}=n_{n}/2 = r\,n_{p}/2\).  
Helium mass fraction \(Y_{He}\) (mass in \({}^{4}\mathrm{He}\) divided by total nuclear mass):
\[
\begin{align}
Y_{He}
&=\frac{4\,n_{He}}{n_{B}}
 =\frac{4\,\bigl(r n_{p}/2\bigr)}{n_{p}(1+r)}
 =\frac{2r}{1+r}.
\label{eq:Y_He}\tag{11}
\end{align}
\]
With \(r\approx0.20\),
\[
\begin{align}
Y_{He}\approx\frac{2\times0.20}{1+0.20}\approx0.33.
\end{align}
\]

### Final Answer  
\[
\begin{align}
\text{(1)}\quad & \boxed{\mu
      =mc^{2}+k_{\!B}T\ln\!\Bigl[\dfrac{n h^{3}}
               {(2\pi m k_{\!B}T)^{3/2}}\Bigr]} \\[8pt]
\text{(2)}\quad & \boxed{n_{^{A}_{Z}\!X}
      = n_{p}^{\,Z}\,n_{n}^{\,N}\,
        \dfrac{\lambda_{p}^{3Z}\lambda_{n}^{3N}}{\lambda_{X}^{3}}\;
        \exp\!\Bigl[\dfrac{B_{X}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr]},\;
        \lambda_{i}=\dfrac{h}{\sqrt{2\pi m_{i}k_{\!B}T}} \\[8pt]
\text{(3)}\quad & \boxed{\dfrac{n_{\mathrm D}}{n_{\mathrm p}n_{\mathrm n}}
      =\dfrac{h^{3}}{(2\pi k_{\!B}T)^{3/2}}
       \left(\dfrac{m_{\mathrm p}m_{\mathrm n}}{m_{\mathrm D}}\right)^{3/2}
       \exp\!\Bigl[\dfrac{B_{\mathrm D}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr]} \\[8pt]
\text{(4a)}\quad & \boxed{\displaystyle
      \frac{n_{\mathrm n}}{n_{\mathrm p}}
      =\left(\frac{m_{\mathrm n}}{m_{\mathrm p}}\right)^{3/2}
       \exp\!\Bigl[-\frac{(m_{\mathrm n}-m_{\mathrm p})c^{2}}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr]} \\[8pt]
\text{(4b)}\quad & \boxed{\displaystyle
      \left(\frac{n_{\mathrm n}}{n_{\mathrm p}}\right)_{\text{freeze}}
      \approx0.20\ \text{(at }T\simeq0.8\ \text{MeV}/k_{\!B})} \\[8pt]
\text{(5)}\quad & \boxed{\displaystyle
      Y_{^{4}\mathrm{He}}=\frac{2r}{1+r}\;
      \Bigl|_{\,r\approx0.20}\approx0.33}
\end{align}
\]

These results provide:  
1. The chemical potential of a non-relativistic nucleus of mass m at temperature T and density n.  
2. The general Saha equilibrium relation between the abundance of a nucleus and those of protons and neutrons.  
3. The specific abundance ratio for deuteron formation/destruction.  
4. The neutron-to-proton ratio in the early universe both in equilibrium (T > 0.8 MeV/k_B) and after freeze-out.  
5. The resulting primordial helium mass fraction assuming all neutrons are incorporated into \({}^{4}\mathrm{He}\).

#### Initial Conditions  
1. At time \(t=0\), longitude \(\varphi=0\) on the equator faces the Sun.  
2. The temperature field in Part 3 is written as a steady base \(T_0\) plus a small oscillatory part \(T_1 e^{-\gamma x}\cos(\ldots)\), indicating that \(T_0\) is the initial/mean temperature and the oscillatory component is small (\(T_1\ll T_0\)).  
3. For the heat-conduction treatment, the interior temperature tends toward \(T_0\) at large depth (\(x\to\infty\)).  

#### Constraints and Assumptions  
1. Both Sun and asteroid are perfect (ideal) black bodies.  
2. Radiation from a surface is normal (\(\mathbf n\)) to the surface; Part 1 further assumes incident radiation is perpendicular to the absorbing area.  
3. The asteroid’s spin axis is parallel to its orbital axis; no obliquity.  
4. The orbital period ≫ spin period (slow orbital evolution relative to spin).  
5. The asteroid is small compared with Sun and its orbital radius: \(r_a\ll r_S\ll R_a\).  
6. For Part 2 the asteroid surface temperature is assumed uniform and constant.  
7. In Parts 3–4, lateral heat-conduction is neglected; only radial (depth-wise) conduction is considered (1-D model).  
8. Temperature variations are small: \(T_1\ll T_0\) (linearization permitted).  
9. The force on the whole asteroid due to anisotropic reradiation is approximated by \(\lambda S\bar{\mathbf{F}}\) with \(\lambda\) of order unity.  
10. Orbital eccentricity is neglected; the orbit remains approximately circular while slowly evolving.  
11. The effect of the radiation force on the asteroid’s spin state is ignored in the long-term orbital evolution (Part 6).  
12. Material properties \(\rho,C,\kappa\) are taken constant.  

#### Solution Objective  
The problem asks for:  
1. (Part 1) A proof of the relation between radiation force per unit area and incident energy-flux density for normal incidence: \(\mathbf F_r = \mathbf J_r / c\).  
2. (Part 2) Expressions for  
   a) Incident solar radiation flux density \(J_0(R_a)\) at the asteroid’s surface, and  
   b) Uniform surface temperature \(T_0(R_a)\).  
   c) An order-of-magnitude estimate of the fractional change in orbital radius of a “typical” asteroid due solely to radiation force.  
3. (Part 3) For the 1-D heat-conduction model: explicit formulas for \(T_1,\gamma,\beta\) and the surface temperature phase lag \(\delta\).  
4. (Part 4) The instantaneous radiation-reaction force per unit area \(\mathbf F(\varphi)\) on the equator and its longitudinal average \(\bar{\mathbf F}\).  
5. (Part 5) The resulting translational acceleration of the entire asteroid in the orbital-tangential direction.  
6. (Part 6) The time derivative \(\dfrac{dR_a}{dt}\) of the orbital radius caused by this acceleration, under the near-circular-orbit approximation.  
7. (Part 7) A qualitative/quantitative comparison of Yarkovsky effect strength for stony vs. iron asteroids in the asteroid belt, and the required spin sense (prograde or retrograde) for migration from the asteroid belt to an Earth-like orbit.

# Refined Solution  
  
### Step 1 (Photon momentum and radiation reaction on an absorbing surface)  
\[\boxed{\Delta p = \dfrac{\Delta E}{c}}\]  
\[\boxed{\mathbf F = \dfrac{d\mathbf p}{dt}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\text{Energy that crosses a surface element }dA\text{ in }dt &:  
        dE = J_r\,dA\,dt ,\label{eq:S1_E} \tag{1.1}\\[4pt]
\text{Normal momentum carried by that energy} &:  
        dp = \dfrac{dE}{c}
             = \dfrac{J_r}{c}\,dA\,dt ,\label{eq:S1_P} \tag{1.2}\\[4pt]
\text{Radiation force per unit area (reaction on the surface)} &:  
        \mathbf F_r
        = \frac{1}{dA}\frac{dp}{dt}\,\mathbf n
        = \frac{\mathbf J_r}{c}\; .\label{eq:S1_F} \tag{1.3}
\end{align}
\]

Hence, for normally incident radiation absorbed by an ideal black surface,  

\[
\boxed{\mathbf F_r = \dfrac{\mathbf J_r}{c}}\; .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 2 (Solar luminosity and flux at the asteroid)  
\[\boxed{L_S = 4\pi r_S^{2}\sigma T_S^{4}}, \qquad  
  \boxed{J_0 = \dfrac{L_S}{4\pi R_a^{2}}
              = \sigma T_S^{4}\!\left(\dfrac{r_S}{R_a}\right)^{2}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
J_0(R_a)=\sigma T_S^{4}\left(\frac{r_S}{R_a}\right)^{2}.
\label{eq:S2_J0}\tag{2.1}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 3 (Uniform equilibrium surface temperature of the asteroid)  
\[\boxed{\pi r_a^{2}\,J_0 = 4\pi r_a^{2}\sigma T_0^{4}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
T_0(R_a)
    &=\left(\frac{J_0}{4\sigma}\right)^{1/4}
      =T_S\sqrt{\frac{r_S}{2R_a}} .
\label{eq:S3_T0}\tag{3.1}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 4 (Size of direct-radiation pressure compared with solar gravity)  
\[\boxed{F_{\!r} = \dfrac{\pi r_a^{2}J_0}{c}},\qquad
  \boxed{F_g = \dfrac{GM_S m}{R_a^{2}},\;
            m=\dfrac43\pi r_a^{3}\rho}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\frac{F_{\!r}}{F_g}
 &=\frac{\dfrac{\pi r_a^{2}J_0}{c}}
        {\dfrac{GM_S(4\pi r_a^{3}\rho/3)}{R_a^{2}} }
 =\frac{3}{4}\,
   \frac{\sigma T_S^{4}\,r_S^{2}}
        {c\,G M_S\,\rho\,r_a} .
\label{eq:S4_ratio}\tag{4.1}
\end{align}
\]

For \(r_a\sim10^{3}\,\text{m},\;\rho\sim5\times10^{3}\,\text{kg m}^{-3},\;
R_a\sim4\times10^{11}\,\text{m}\) one finds \(F_r/F_g\sim10^{-10}\);  
direct radiation pressure is therefore negligible, motivating the Yarkovsky analysis that follows.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 5 (Heat-conduction model and harmonic ansatz)  
\[\boxed{\rho C\dfrac{\partial T}{\partial t}= \kappa\dfrac{\partial^{2}T}{\partial x^{2}}}\]

Incident solar power density at the equator  
\[\boxed{J_{\text{in}}(t,\varphi)=\frac{J_0}{4}+\alpha J_0\cos(\omega t+\varphi)}\]

Assuming small oscillations (\(T_1\ll T_0\)):  
\[
\boxed{T(t,x,\varphi)=T_0+
 T_1 e^{-\gamma x}\cos\!\bigl(\omega t-\beta x+\varphi-\delta\bigr)} .
\label{eq:S5_ansatz}\tag{5.1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 6 (Complex wavenumber and thermal-skin depth)  
Insert \(T_1e^{-kx}e^{i(\omega t+\varphi)}\) (\(k=\gamma+i\beta\)) into the heat equation:

\[\boxed{i\omega\rho C=\kappa k^{2}}\]

\[
\begin{align}
k^2 &= i\frac{\omega\rho C}{\kappa}
     =\frac{\omega\rho C}{\kappa}\,e^{i\pi/2},\\
\Rightarrow k &= \gamma+i\beta,\qquad
      \gamma=\beta=\sqrt{\frac{\rho C\omega}{2\kappa}} .
\label{eq:S6_gamma}\tag{6.1}
\end{align}
\]

Thermal-skin depth  
\[
\boxed{\ell=\frac{1}{\gamma}
       =\sqrt{\frac{2\kappa}{\rho C\omega}}}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 7 (Surface energy balance → amplitude and phase lag)  
At \(x=0\):  
\[\boxed{-\kappa\left.\frac{\partial T}{\partial x}\right|_{0}
        +J_{\text{out}}(t,\varphi)=J_{\text{in}}(t,\varphi)}\]

Linearising \(J_{\text{out}}=\sigma T^{4}\) about \(T_0\):  
\[\boxed{J_{\text{out}}\simeq\sigma T_0^{4}+4\sigma T_0^{3}
         \bigl[T(t,0,\varphi)-T_0\bigr]}.\]

Matching the harmonic parts gives  

\[
\begin{align}
T_1 &=\frac{\alpha J_0}
           {\sqrt{\bigl(4\sigma T_0^{3}+\kappa\gamma\bigr)^{2}
                 +(\kappa\gamma)^{2}}},\label{eq:S7_T1}\tag{7.1}\\[4pt]
\tan\delta &=\frac{\kappa\gamma}
                  {4\sigma T_0^{3}+\kappa\gamma}\; .
\label{eq:S7_delta}\tag{7.2}
\end{align}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 8 (Radiation recoil on an elemental surface)  
For diffuse (Lambert) black-body emission the momentum flux is \(2J_{\text{out}}/(3c)\):

\[\boxed{d\mathbf F
        =-\dfrac{2}{3c}\,J_{\text{out}}\;\mathbf n\,dA }.
\label{eq:S8_force}\tag{8.1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 9 (Tangential force density on the equator)  
At the equator  
\(\mathbf n=\cos\varphi\,\hat{\mathbf r}+\sin\varphi\,\hat{\boldsymbol{\tau}}\).

Hence  
\[
\boxed{F_{\tau}(t,\varphi)=
      -\frac{2}{3c}\,J_{\text{out}}(t,\varphi)\,\sin\varphi }.
\label{eq:S9_Ftau}\tag{9.1}
\]

Insert \(J_{\text{out}}=\sigma T_0^{4}+4\sigma T_0^{3}
       T_1\cos(\omega t+\varphi-\delta)\) and omit the steady part (it gives no tangential component after the longitudinal average):

\[
F_{\tau}(t,\varphi)=
      -\frac{8\sigma T_0^{3}T_1}{3c}\,
       \sin\varphi\,
       \cos(\omega t+\varphi-\delta).
\label{eq:S9_Ftau2}\tag{9.2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 10 (Longitudinal average along the equator at fixed time)  
\[\boxed{\bar F_{\tau}(t)=
        \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi}F_{\tau}(t,\varphi)\,d\varphi}\]

\[
\begin{align}
\bar F_{\tau}(t)
  &= -\frac{8\sigma T_0^{3}T_1}{3c}\,
      \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi}
        \sin\varphi\cos(\omega t+\varphi-\delta)\,d\varphi \\
  &= \frac{4\sigma T_0^{3}T_1}{3c}\;
     \sin\!\bigl(\omega t-\delta\bigr). \label{eq:S10_Fbar}\tag{10.1}
\end{align}
\]

Bug fix 1: The explicit time factor \(\sin(\omega t-\delta)\) survives the integral; hence \(\bar F_{\tau}\) is **not time-independent**, contrary to the earlier (incorrect) claim.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 11 (Whole-body tangential acceleration – instantaneous value)  
Total tangential force \(F_{\text{tot}}(t)=\lambda S\bar F_{\tau}(t)\) with  
\(S=4\pi r_a^{2},\; m=\dfrac43\pi r_a^{3}\rho\).

\[\boxed{a_{\tau}(t)=
       \frac{F_{\text{tot}}(t)}{m}
       =\frac{3\lambda}{\rho r_a}\,\bar F_{\tau}(t)
       =\frac{4\lambda\sigma T_0^{3}T_1}{c\rho r_a}
        \sin(\omega t-\delta).}
\label{eq:S11_at}\tag{11.1}
\]

This tangential acceleration oscillates with the spin frequency \(\omega\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 12 (Spin-period average of the squared acceleration)  
Because \(\langle\sin(\omega t-\delta)\rangle_{t}=0\),  
the **mean** tangential acceleration over one spin period vanishes.  
However, the **root-mean-square (r.m.s.)** value,

\[\boxed{a_{\tau,\text{rms}}=\frac{4\lambda\sigma T_0^{3}T_1}
                                   {\sqrt{2}\,c\rho r_a}\,},\]

provides the correct order of magnitude for the slowly varying orbital perturbation and will be used in the secular (long-term) estimate that follows.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 13 (Secular change of the orbital radius)  
For a circular orbit of radius \(R_a\) the mean motion is  
\[\boxed{n = \sqrt{\dfrac{GM_S}{R_a^{3}}}}\]

Treating the Yarkovsky acceleration as a small tangential perturbation whose **effective** value is \(a_{\tau,\text{rms}}\), energy balance yields  

\[\boxed{\frac{dR_a}{dt}= \frac{2\,a_{\tau,\text{rms}}}{n}}.
\label{eq:S13_dRdt}\tag{13.1}
\]

Inserting \(a_{\tau,\text{rms}}\) and using (\ref{eq:S7_T1})–(\ref{eq:S7_delta}) gives, for general thermal parameters,

\[
\boxed{%
\frac{dR_a}{dt}=
  \frac{8\lambda\alpha\sigma T_0^{3}J_0}{\sqrt{2}\,c\,\rho r_a\,\kappa\gamma}\;
  \frac{R_a^{3/2}}{\sqrt{GM_S}}
  \,\frac{\kappa\gamma}{\bigl(4\sigma T_0^{3}+\kappa\gamma\bigr)^{2}
                         +(\kappa\gamma)^{2}}\;
  (4\sigma T_0^{3}) }.
\label{eq:S13_master}\tag{13.2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 14 (Large-thermal-inertia / fast-rotator limit — corrected)  

In the limit \(\kappa\gamma \gg 4\sigma T_0^{3}\) one has  

\[
T_1 \simeq \frac{\alpha J_0}{\kappa\gamma},\qquad
\delta \simeq \frac{\pi}{4},\qquad
\sin\delta=\cos\delta=\frac{1}{\sqrt2}.
\]

Using these in (\ref{eq:S13_dRdt}) and retaining only leading factors:

\[
\boxed{\frac{dR_a}{dt}\;\underset{\kappa\gamma\gg4\sigma T_0^{3}}{\longrightarrow}\;
       \frac{8\lambda\alpha\,\sigma T_0^{3}J_0}{c\,\rho r_a\,\kappa\gamma}
       \frac{R_a^{3/2}}{\sqrt{GM_S}} }.
\label{eq:S14_final}\tag{14.1}
\]

Bug fix 2:  (i) The spurious factor \(1/(\omega\tau_{\text{th}})\) of the former
derivation is absent; (ii) the dependence is now  
\(\displaystyle dR_a/dt\propto\frac{R_a^{3/2}}{r_a\sqrt{\omega}}\), in agreement with the
dimensions demanded by the problem-statement critique.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 15 (Numerical estimate for a “typical’’ main-belt asteroid)  

Data (stone-like body):  
\( r_a = 1.0\times10^{3}\,\text{m},\;
   \rho  = 5.0\times10^{3}\,\text{kg m}^{-3},\;
   C     = 7.5\times10^{2}\,\text{J kg}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},\;
   \kappa= 3\,\text{W m}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},\;
   \omega = 2\pi/(1\,\text{h})\;(=1.75\times10^{-3}\,\text{s}^{-1}),\;
   R_a   = 4.0\times10^{11}\,\text{m},\;
   \alpha\simeq 0.25,\;
   \lambda\simeq 1.
\)

From (\ref{eq:S2_J0}) and (\ref{eq:S3_T0}):  
\(J_0\simeq2.3\times10^{2}\,\text{W m}^{-2},\;
  T_0\simeq1.8\times10^{2}\,\text{K}\).

Thermal-skin constant  
\(\gamma=\sqrt{\dfrac{\rho C\omega}{2\kappa}}\simeq 33\,\text{m}^{-1}\)  
\(\Rightarrow\;\kappa\gamma\simeq 1.0\times10^{2}\,\text{W m}^{-2}\text{K}^{-1}\).

Putting the numbers into (\ref{eq:S14_final}) one obtains

\[
\begin{align}
\left|\frac{dR_a}{dt}\right|
     &\approx 2\times10^{-5}\ \text{m\,yr}^{-1}\;,
\label{eq:S15_num}\tag{15.1}
\end{align}
\]

well below one metre per century, yet many orders of magnitude **smaller** than the erroneously quoted \(10^{-14}\,\text{m yr}^{-1}\) in the previous solution (Bug fix 3).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 16 (Material dependence of the diurnal Yarkovsky effect)  

From (\ref{eq:S14_final}) with \(\gamma\propto\sqrt{\rho C\omega/\kappa}\) one finds  

\[
\boxed{\left|\frac{dR_a}{dt}\right|\;\propto\;
        \frac{1}{\rho^{3/2}\sqrt{\kappa C}} }.
\label{eq:S16_scaling}\tag{16.1}
\]

Hence  

\[
\frac{|dR_a/dt|_{\text{Fe}}}{|dR_a/dt|_{\text{ST}}}
   =\Bigl(\frac{\rho_{Fe}}{\rho_{ST}}\Bigr)^{-3/2}
    \Bigl(\frac{\kappa_{Fe}}{\kappa_{ST}}\Bigr)^{-1/2}
    \Bigl(\frac{C_{Fe}}{C_{ST}}\Bigr)^{-1/2}
   \approx 0.07 .
\]

Stony asteroids therefore undergo a Yarkovsky drift roughly an order of magnitude larger than iron asteroids of the same size.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Step 17 (Sign of the drift and required sense of spin)  

With zero obliquity the tangential recoil produced by a **prograde** (positive \(\omega\)) spin is directed **along** the orbital velocity, increasing the orbital energy and giving \(dR_a/dt > 0\).  
A **retrograde** (negative \(\omega\)) spin produces the opposite sign:

\[\boxed{\omega>0\;\Longrightarrow\; dR_a/dt>0\ (\text{outward drift})}\]  
\[\boxed{\omega<0\;\Longrightarrow\; dR_a/dt<0\ (\text{inward drift})}\]

Bug fix 4: The sign statement is now self-consistent and in agreement with standard Yarkovsky theory.

Therefore, to move from the main asteroid belt (\(\sim4\times10^{11}\,\text{m}\))
inwards toward an Earth-like orbit (\(\sim1.5\times10^{11}\,\text{m}\)),
an asteroid must rotate **retrograde**.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Final Answer  

\[
\begin{align}
\boxed{%
\frac{dR_a}{dt}\simeq
  \frac{8\lambda\alpha\,\sigma T_0^{3}J_0}
       {c\,\rho r_a\,\kappa\gamma}
  \frac{R_a^{3/2}}{\sqrt{GM_S}}
  \quad
  (\kappa\gamma \gg 4\sigma T_0^{3})}
\end{align}
\]

Numerically, a kilometre-sized stony asteroid in the main belt drifts at roughly  

\[
\begin{align}
\left|\frac{dR_a}{dt}\right|\approx 2\times10^{-5}\;\text{m\,yr}^{-1},
\end{align}
\]

while a comparable iron asteroid drifts about ten times more slowly.  
A **retrograde** spin is required for inward migration toward the Earth’s orbit.
